glance/async_/flows/api_image_import.py.message: This needs to be here as it is as if all_stores_must_succeed is true it will never add the failure store to the list as we don't call revert in that case.
Ah, right, I made this change while tweaking the unit tests but forgot that we'd skip in that case.

We should be adding this to the failed stores anyways as we're removing the store on L: 516 as the data is not there even it was part of the request.

I don't know what else might cause us calling this revert than the task itself failing and if the answer is nothing, the check in L 518 is redundant.

Or what we likely should do is to move that L 516 under this check so we remove the location data only if we really failed.

> IMO user will able to understand that his import operation
 > has been stopped when he  will see that all_stores_must_succeed is
 > True and there is one store in the os_glance_failed_import list.

This was my take as well. I would expect if all must succeed, and I only see a few, then that would give me a clue what happened.

it was my suggestion to add only store to failed list which caused the actual failure (even dan was insisting to add all the stores which will be reverted). I insisted the same because when you go through the logs you can find that the image was imported to some stores before it was failed while importing to 'xyz' store which caused removing the data from previous stores.

In the spec it is not mentioned after deleting the data from previous stores they will be shown in the os_glance_failed_import list. IMO user will able to understand that his import operation has been stopped when he  will see that all_stores_must_succeed is True and there is one store in the os_glance_failed_import list.

I am also open for adding all the stores to failed list as dan and you find it more user friendly.

But that's not what the spec [0] says. Unless I understood the failure differently than the rest.

The whole point of those two parameters were to track the progress which stores of the request are done and which are not as per of the store list. So if we add only one store into the failure list it may leave the user wondering what happened to the rest of the stores in for that import. It will be impossible to know if that import is still running or not.

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/ussuri/approved/glance/import-multi-stores.html#proposed-change

nova/conf/novnc.py.message:
There should be a release note for this new config option.


https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/releasenotes.html
ssl_options was added to websockify at the same time, is there any need to define something for that as well?

Adding ssl_options is not as straight-forward as ssl_ciphers.  The ssl_options are really OpenSSL constants that need to be set in code.  In websockify, they exposed a new CLI parameter --ssl-version, which has string parsing logic that translates their own config values into the appropriate constants that are used when creating the OpenSSL context:

 https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/master/websockify/websocketproxy.py#L494-L496

 https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/master/websockify/websocketproxy.py#L397-L442

This is not exposed for us to use, so I unfortunately think that we would need to have our own config parsing for this here in nova.
Actually, the parsing code is exposed to us from websockify.  I'll update the patch to use that to allow us to set a minimum TLS version.

Good catch on ssl_options.  It needs to be added to control the TLS protocol versions.  I will add this.

Ack on adding the release note.  That will come in the next patch revision.

Should this only be set if ssl_only=True? If so, we should call that out as a related option (and vice-versa, ssl_only would call out ssl_ciphers as a related option).

When I say related options in the help, I mean like this:

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#DEFAULT.vif_plugging_timeout
So, this is a comma-delimited or space delimited list? If it's an actual list, we should use ListOpt.

> So, this is a comma-delimited or space delimited list? If it's an
 > actual list, we should use ListOpt.

Looks like websockify calls this:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl.SSLContext.set_ciphers

Which I eventually found my way to:

https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man1/openssl-ciphers.html

And then I found the "CIPHER LIST FORMAT" section in there. The help text here should definitely point to some documentation on what the format of the string should be, which is maybe just linking to this:

https://www.openssl.org/docs/manmaster/man1/openssl-ciphers.html

I should perhaps reword this.  It is technically an "OpenSSL cipher preference list" as OpenSSL refers to it, which is a single string as far as python is concerned.  An example value is something like this:

  'kEECDH+aECDSA+AES:kEECDH+AES+aRSA:kEDH+aRSA+AES'

You can see details here if interested:

  https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.0.2/man1/ciphers.html

My understanding of ssl_only=True is that it rejects connections that don't use TLS.  Isn't it still possible to accept connections that are in clear-text as well as TLS without setting this option if the cert and key are provided via configuration?

Perhaps this would be better mentioned as being related to the 'cert' option since that is the setting that enables TLS.  There are no other related options listed there now, but I can add all of the TLS options there (key, ssl_only, etc.) if you feel it would be best done in this patch.
IMHO, it would be friendly to link to the man page here and also provide an example cipher preference string.
nit: it might be worth a comment that these values must align with the SSL_OPTIONS in websockify/websocketproxy.py

nova/console/websocketproxy.py.message:
To test this, I suggest adding a mock of select_ssl_version to the test_proxy test and mock_select_ssl_version.assert_not_called(). That will verify that we don't call select_ssl_version when ssl_min_verison='default'

Then, in another test, init a proxy with select_ssl_version set to one of the choices and then verify mock_select_ssl_version was called with the expected value. That test can also set ssl_ciphers to a cipher preference string and then verify mock_init was called with the expected value for ssl_ciphers. That will verify that the value set by the user for ssl_ciphers gets passed to init as expected.
Thanks for the pointers!  I have added the recommended tests in the next patch revision.
None is not a valid value for this option so why not default to 'default'? I guess it's valid if the kwarg isn't specified though, like in some unit tests that don't care about this.

This is because 'default' is the least secure option in websockify (ssl.OPT_ALL).  The default behavior should be hardened as much as possible, which is what I tried to explain in the above comment.  None is a valid option, which should trigger websockify's fallback behavior as seen in this else clause:

https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/websocketproxy.py#L432-L442

Note that this will use the most secure option, which can vary depending on Python version or over time as new TLS protocol versions come into use.

None is not an option for the ssl_minimum_version config option in nova - that's my point. Since in non-test runtime code NovaWebSocketProxy is always getting passed ssl_minimum_version based on the config option, and the config option choices don't allow for None, that's why this wouldn't be None in runtime, but I said it's possible if the kwarg isn't specified for example in test code.

Anyway, there is nothing really to change here.

There is no testing for this logic:

https://48a12864234aa2205a2e-b0513d7a5caaf512c62df58e84959553.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/679502/9/check/openstack-tox-cover/062df1b/cover/nova_console_websocketproxy_py.html#n327
I've added unit tests for this logic.
or was not set by the user (ssl_minimum_version defaults to 'default')

This is always going to be true because NovaWebSocketProxy.__init__ is what calls it and you've mocked that method.

You should have a test for NovaWebSocketProxy.__init__ which doesn't mock __init__ but does mock select_ssl_version to make sure it's doing what you want with the logic.
I've removed this assertion, and added tests for NovaWebSocketProxy.__init__()

This is a lie, right? If ssl_minimum_version is not 'default' then select_ssl_version is going to return a value, in this case:

https://github.com/novnc/websockify/blob/v0.9.0/websockify/websocketproxy.py#L405

I mean it's fine to mock select_ssl_version and let it return a mock, but it wouldn't return None.

Actually, you don't even need this mock because you've mocked NovaWebSocketProxy.__init__.
Yes, it looks like select_ssl_version will always return something.  You're right that we don't need to mock it in this test, so I've removed this mock.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
I don't think we actually need this since we're not raising a different exception here. This would be necessary if we were doing e.g.

  raise NewException('foo')

and didn't want to include any context from the original exception. However, I don't think that's the case here. Consider:

    def foo():
        try:
            x = 5 / 0
            print(x)
        except Exception:
            raise Exception('This failed')
    foo()

which raises:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "test.py", line 3, in foo
        x = 5 / 0
    ZeroDivisionError: division by zero

    During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "test.py", line 9, in <module>
        foo()
      File "test.py", line 6, in foo
        raise Exception('This failed')
    Exception: This failed

whereas if we use 'raise from None', we see:

    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "test.py", line 9, in <module>
        foo()
      File "test.py", line 6, in foo
        raise Exception('This failed') from None
    Exception: This failed
Can we inline this function here? (same comment later)

Hi, Julia:
Thanks for the comment! As I understood, ironic used WSME for three: the first and most cases were parameters checking, ironic used data types derived from WSME at API to reach the purpose. the second was function library, this is to do, but not too much effort, just replace some function of WSME with other way would be fine.  My patch already showed how to do parameters checking by json schema, we could use this way at all APIs. 

But there was one big problem at the third one, function expose. Ironic still used WSME decorator to expose API, but this expose function depends on web framework used. it should be the responsibility of flask owner to replace pecan as I understand now.

So my plan was:
1. Add json schema function at all places where WSME checked API parameters such as uuid or string.
2. Replace all WSME library function  by other function or other library. For example, some code use WSME's date time library function to get date or time.
3. After flask replaced pecan, remove all WSME parameter checking code and add the json schema decorator to the right place of API at new framework.

originally, my thoughts was like yours, need to do it like WSME did like below:

If I'm listed as "Jeremy Stanley" but set my Gerrit display name to "Jeremy Stanley (fungi)" it will still match. I have to assume we wouldn't list people as just "Tony" but you're right there's the slight chance that one person's display name could be an initial subset of someone else's. It would also be possible for one person to intentionally set their name to a superset of another and then trigger this with a vote, but the odds of that going unnoticed are relatively slim and also there's nothing stopping someone from triggering this today by simply having the same display name as the person recorded in the list. Gerrit doesn't require these to be unique. If we want that, we should match on E-mail address or Gerrit account number.

Yeah, now the chance is little more for false matching. 
I think email matching is a good way and we do not have only 3 delegates tag so it is not a huge list.

not that we should do this in this review, but I wonder if it would make sense for us to start leveraging the nmcli module, and/or the openvswitch_{db,bridge,port} modules instead of the script?

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/nmcli_module.html
https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/openvswitch_bridge_module.html

We could probably even keep the JSON file parsing: simply parse the input directly using the aforementioned modules.

I doubt it. But the point of extracting this out is that we can start investigating these. Right now it's a 1:1 port from THT. The script it self actually comes from a generated thing in THT (which seems wrong) via a Heat SoftwareConfig

https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/network/scripts/run-os-net-config.sh#L8-L11

My goal is to get this cut over and then we can kill off the SoftwareConfig and make this stuff less bash-scripty.  The issue with trying to use like the nmcli configs (besides the lack of SRIOV/DPDK/etc support), is that we'll break existing integration with os-net-config.  

Since this can actually nuke the connectivity while executing, a single ansible module replacement that can be run async is likely a better replacement than trying to leverage those other modules.
while I can see the value in having the debug info, I wonder if it makes sense to just add the `failed_when` property to the above task to limit task proliferation?
This is a port from the existing code (no idea why it was written this way). But I believe it still debug's the output in the failure case but just stops here
Yea actually it fails in the molecule test with out stderr_lines (there's no stderr). Normal os-net-config spits out stderr always
This needs to be a template because the script we get passed in is a template. Unfortunately remote_src doesn't work with template so this will be annoying.

ironic/drivers/modules/drac/raid.py.message:
Here, if using python-dracclient 3.0.0, conversion_results won't exist in the dict.  So we need to check if it is present.  If not, then loop through the list of IDs in change_disk_state['commit_required_ids'] and construct a controller like below and add it to the controllers list.
- For raid_controller, use the ID from commit_required_ids that we're currently iterating on
- For is_reboot_required, use the value of change_disk_state['is_reboot_required']
- For is_commit_required, use True

This should make it work with the 3.0.0 version of python-dracclient, but it will make it not use realtime mode when doing the conversion, which I think is ok.  It will still do the conversion, but just be slower.

test-requirements.txt.message:
If I am not wrong 15.3.1 is horizon stable/stein version[1]?
[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/src/branch/master/deliverables/stein/horizon.yaml#L44

ok, thanks for the info.
One more thing that I notice most of the plugins uses horizon in their 'requirement.txt'[1].
Can we do the same here as the same thing done for openstack/cloudkitty-dashboard master version?
http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=horizon%3E%3D&i=nope&files=requirements.txt&repos=

stable/ussuri (and thus master) have already switched to use requirements.txt in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/700839/

It feels odd to add a requirement to a stable release, but I guess that's the right thing to do?

It is the maximum version from Stein, yes. The idea was that that would be the absolute minimum version that could be installed. But then typical pip installation will grab the highest version available, limited by whatever is specified as a constraint (pip -c [path to stable/train upper-constraints.txt]). So it should always pick up the final release, and any updated stable releases, or horizon for stable/stein.

Yeah, I don't really know this project well enough, but I would assume horizon is more than just a test requirement for it. I would recommend reviewing whether that is actually the case, and if so, propose a follow up patch on master to switch it to requirements.txt.
I guess, if we define the requirement for a library, we should set it to a closed and released version.

bindep.txt.message:
we spoke about this on irc a bit.
while this is not really a nova dep
if nova is deploy with cinder one of nova or cinder will need to provide this if we don't use LIBS_FROM_GIT=os-brick

And just to clarify a bit, in any case where nova needs to access a cinder volume, so I guess any n-compute nodes, it uses os-brick to perform those local storage management steps to discover the new volume. The latest os-brick switched how some of this device discovery is done to use lsscsi as a much faster and more efficient way of finding it.

The down side to this is the previous package, sg_scan, was available by default on all our nodes, but lsscsi isn't. It is packaged for all of our supported platforms, just not pulled in already by any of our other packages that are there by default.

So this just makes sure when it comes time for nova to call into os-brick, the expected utility will be available. Since doing a "pip install os-brick" won't process os-brick's bindep file, we need to call it out here.
